questions.text: A patient presented with bitemporal hemianopia. On imaging it is found that an artery aneurysm is pressing on optic chiasma .What is the likely artery involved?
questions.solution:
• At the optic chiasm, the nasal fibers of the optic nerve decussate.
  • These crossed fibers are more damaged than the uncrossed fibers.
  • This leads to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • The structures that are close to the optic chiasm include the anterior communicating artery and the pituitary stalk.
  • Aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery or mass lesions of the sella cause this visual field defect.

questions.text: A 50 years old male presented with fatigability for one year. Evaluation showed mild anemia, massive splenomegaly. Hb- 10gm%, ILC of 120 x 10(3), platelet 500 x 10(3), neutrophils 60, basophils 4, eosinophils 6, lymphocytes 15. Also seen were myeloblasts, myelocytes metamyelocytes and bands. M: E ratio 8:1. What is the most sensitive investigation?
questions.solution:
• The age, the symptoms and the presence of massive splenomegaly points towards a myeloproliferative disorder.
  • From the peripheral smear, we can see that there is an increase in neutrophils with a shift to left having band forms, myelocytes and metamyelocytes and an increase in myeloid erythroid ratio classical of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia.
  • The cytogenetic abnormality seen in 90% of patients with CML is the reciprocal translocation between chromosome 9 and 22.
  • This translocation can be identified by the technique of FISH and PCR.

Immunophenotyping is a process used to identify the cells based on the antigens on their surface. It cannot be used for identifying chromosomal anomalies.

FDG PET is the imaging technique used to identify areas of increased metabolism as in malignancy or infections. It can help us to identify the organ involved, but doesn't help in identifying the type of disease.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase measures the alkaline phosphatase in neutrophils.

  • Its value is high in leukemoid reaction, tissue damage, steroid use, OCP, aplastic anemia, hodgkin's lymphoma and Down syndrome.
  • It is elevated in myeloproliferative disorders, but is low in the chronic phase of CML. It is low in PNH and hereditary hypophosphatemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indicator for poor prognosis in a case of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
The single most powerful predictor of survival is β2 microglobulin. It can substitute for staging.

S albumin and β2 microglobulin alone are used for staging Myeloma known as the International Staging System(ISS) and has replaced the Durie salmon staging.

INTERNATIONAL STAGING SYSTEM

Other poor prognostic factors in myeloma are- High labelling index, circulating plasma cells, poor performance status and high LDH levels.

Chromosomal anomalies and Risk stratification:

  • No aneuploidy in karyotyping, t(11,14) and del 13 are associated with standard risk and a survival of 6-7 years.
  • Presence of any aneuploidy in karyotyping is associated with a high risk. Any other chromosomal anomaly than mentioned above is associated with high risk. 2-3 year survival.
  • The ISS, when used along with the cytogenetic changes, forms the basis of the Revised ISS for staging.

questions.text: A person worked in the benzene industry for 20 years. He now complains of fatigue and frequent infection. Which of the occupational cancers is most likely?
questions.solution:
The question is based on chemical carcinogens. Benzene is used in industries as a solvent and is linked to AML. Benzene is also an agent notorious for bone marrow failure and aplasia.

Bladder cancer is seen with alkylating agents.

Skin cancer is seen with Arsenic.

Asbestos Arsenic and chromium are associated with lung cancer.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: A software engineer presents with fatigue. He is having a sedentary life, mostly sitting in front of a computer for 12-14 hours. He takes junk food, and is not eating vegetables and fruits. Hb 9, MCV 120. What is the most likely etiology
questions.solution:
Our patient is having a macrocytic anemia, which easily rules out options c and d.

  • Macrocytic anemia can be seen in either Folate or Vit B12 deficiency.
  • The chief source of Vitamin B12 is animal and dairy products.
  • Folic acid however is ubiquitous and is seen in most of the foods, but is easily destroyed by cooking.
  • So in a person who eats junk food and does not consume fruits or vegetables, the most likely cause of macrocytic anemia is folate deficiency.

B12 Deficiency (Option A):

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause macrocytic anemia.

However, B12 deficiency is less likely in this scenario because it typically presents with additional neurological symptoms (e.g., tingling, numbness, balance issues).

Folate Deficiency (Option B):

Folate deficiency is a common cause of macrocytic anemia.

Folate (vitamin B9) is essential for RBC production and DNA synthesis.

Poor dietary intake (especially lacking vegetables and fruits) can lead to folate deficiency.

Given the sedentary lifestyle and junk food consumption, folate deficiency is a plausible explanation.

Acute Blood Loss (Option C):

Acute blood loss can cause anemia, but it typically results in normocytic or microcytic anemia.

The elevated MCV (macrocytosis) doesn't align with acute blood loss.

Sideroblastic Anemia (Option D):

Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by abnormal iron metabolism within RBC precursors.

It usually presents with microcytic or normocytic anemia.

Sideroblastic anemia is less likely based on the given information.

In summary, considering the elevated MCV and the lifestyle factors, folate deficiency is the most likely cause of macrocytic anemia in this case

Following tables depict the causes of B12 and folate deficiency:

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with this condition. She has a dog as a pet. What would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
The lesion given in the figure depicts a boggy swelling of the scalp with pustules and scarring alopecia, characteristic of Kerion.

  • These are infections by dermatophytic fungi- Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton, which classically infect the skin, hair and nails.
  • These organisms are not a component of the normal skin flora.
  • Several species cause infections in cats and dogs and several of them are found in soil and spread from these two sources.
  • The classical lesion caused is the ringworm. The infection of the scalp is called Tinea Capitis and is caused by Trichophyton tonsurans. T tonsurans and Microsporum canis cause Kerion.
  • Topical therapy is generally ineffective as monotherapy for scalp infections and shoiu;ld be combined with systemic agents.
  • Topical ketoconazole or selenium sulphate along with oral Griseofulvin, terbinafine or Itraconazole is the

Epidermoid Cyst: These are non-cancerous bumps that develop beneath the skin. They are usually found on the face, neck, or trunk and are slow-growing and painless. They may have a blackhead plugging the central opening and can leak a thick, cheesy substance if ruptured or removed. They don't typically require treatment unless they become painful or infected.

Abscess: An abscess is a painful, red, swollen infection filled with pus. It can form on the skin or inside the body. Abscesses are usually caused by bacteria and can cause symptoms elsewhere in the body. Unlike cysts, which grow slowly, an abscess can appear quickly and is often accompanied by fever or other systemic symptoms2.

Folliculitis: This is the inflammation of hair follicles on the skin. It appears as small, red bumps that may have a white, pus-filled tip. Folliculitis can be itchy or irritating and is often caused by bacterial infection, although it can also result from fungal infections, irritation, or physical injury to the hair follicles.

questions.text: A patient presented with tendon xanthoma and has high total cholesterol and high LDL. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Familial hypercholesterolemia is associated with tendon xanthomas and ASCVD risk. In this group lysosomal acid lipase deficiency is associated with micronodular cirrhosis.

Hypertriglyceridemia is seen in familial chylomicronemia syndrome and familial partial lipodystrophy. They are associated with eruptive xanthomas and pancreatitis.

Tangiers disease is associated with very low HDL and is associated with peripheral neuropathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Other diseases associated with low HDL are as follows:

Primary hypolipidemias

In this group abeta liporoteinemia is characterized by spinocerebellar degeneration and retinal degeneration.

Mixed dyslipidemia:

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with increasing abdominal girth and decreased liver span. Liver biopsy shows hepatocytes with eosinophilic material cytokeratin positive. What is the content of the inclusions?
questions.solution:
In a chronic alcoholic patient with deceased liver span the diagnosis is Alcoholic liver disease which can be steatosis, hepatitis or cirrhosis. In a patient who continues to consume alcohol, a combination of the three can be seen.

  1. Alcoholic steatosis is characterised by the presence of microvesicular steatosis.
  2. Alcoholic hepatitis is characterized by Ballooned hepatocytes, where the hepatocytes are damaged with cleared out cytoplasm and with extensive cytoskeletal damage resulting in eosinophilic bodies called Mallory Hyaline, which are intermediate filaments-Keratin 8 and Keratin I8(Hence they stain positive for cytokeratin)
  3. Inflammation and necrosis
    • Perivenular fibrosis: initially appear as chicken wire fibrosis. Later leads to periportal and bridging fibrosis known as Laennec Cirrhosis
    • Cirrhosis liver is characterized microscopically by the presence of parenchymal nodules surrounded by areas of fibrosis throughout the liver, resulting in the formation of nodules.
    • Fibrosis can be stained using Masson's Trichrome.

So, under light microscope the intermediate filaments appear as Mallory hyaline which are seen collapsed into the cell and they stain positive for cytokeratin.

questions.text: A diabetic female patient admitted with persistent vomiting with a history of consuming food from outside. BP-90/60mmHg; pH 7.52; HCo3- 26; Paco2 20+. Electrolytes Na- 123, K+- 3.2, Cl- 67meq/l. What is the cause of her ABG findings?
questions.solution:
The pH is 7.52 which is alkalotic, the HCO3 is 26, which is high or at the upper limit of normal, so the acid base abnormality is metabolic alkalosis.

Among the given options only persistent vomiting will cause metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A patient with loss of the right half of the visual field loss on both sides. What would the probable diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
Lesion of the optic tract and beyond will lead to contralateral homonymous hemianopia Damage to the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) produces a superior quadrantic homonymous hemianopia (lesion marked as J).

  • Lesions of the optic nerve will result in total blindness in the ipsilateral eye.
  • Lesion of the optic chiasm will lead to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Injury to the optic radiations in the parietal lobe results in an inferior quadrantic homonymous hemianopia (K).
  • Lesions of the primary visual cortex give rise to dense, congruous hemianopic field defects. Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery supplying the occipital lobe is a common cause of total homonymous hemianopia. Some patients have macular sparing, because the central field representation at the tip of the occipital lobe is supplied by collaterals from the middle cerebral artery (L).
  • Destruction of both occipital lobes produces cortical blindness. This condition can be distinguished from bilateral prechiasmal visual loss by noting that the pupil responses and optic fundi remain normal.

choices.text: Alprazolam 0.5 mg one tab OD for 7 days
Alprazolam 1/2 mg one tab HS for 7 days
Alprazolam 0.5 mg one tab bedtime for 7 days
Alprazolam 500 mcg one tab at bedtime for 7 days

questions.text: Being a medical practitioner in India, how would you correctly prescribe alprazolam?
questions.solution:
Alprazolam is an anxiolytic benzodiazepine available in 0.25 and 0.5mg tablets.

Its prescribed at bedtime Tab.

Alprazolam 0.5mg one at bed time(HS) will be the correct prescription.

choices.text: Diagnosed by urine VMA and catecholamines
Treatment of choice is surgical excision
Propranolol is given initially to treat hypertension
Can present as hypertension alone, sometimes with abdominal pain and vomiting

questions.text: Which among the following are false statements regarding pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
In the medical management of pheochromocytoma, the initial drug given is alpha adrenergic blockers, usually oral Phentolamine 0.5-4 mg/kg body weight.

While adequate alpha blockade is being achieved, any paroxysms of hypertension should be managed by either oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine.

Beta blockers are added later on.

If therapy is initiated with beta blocker alone, the catecholamines will act on the alpha receptors and will result in acute hypertensive crisis.

questions.text: A CKD patient undergoing pyeloplasty. What is the best suited post op analgesic?
questions.solution:
The best analgesic for a patient with CKD is acetaminophen among the given options.

NSAIDS are contraindicated in renal impairment.

  • The normal glomerular filtration pressure is maintained by dilation of the afferent arteriole by prostaglandins and constriction of the efferent arteriole by Angiotensin II, in case of reduced perfusion pressure within the autoregulatory range.
  • If NSAIDS are used, loss of vasodilatory prostaglandins occur and the glomerular capillary pressure decreases and the GFR falls.

ARBs or ACEI cause reduction in Angiotensin II and leads to loss of constriction of efferent arteriole and reduced glomerular capillary pressure and the GFR falls.

questions.text: A patient with excessive tiredness towards the end of the day which improves with rest. He also has ptosis, speech difficulty. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given question, a fatigable weakness which improves with rest is classical Myasthenia gravis.

Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome is similar to myasthenia Gravis but is differentiated by

  • Absence of reflexes
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Antibodies are directed against the pre synaptic P/Q type Ca channels.
  • Proximal muscles of the lower limb are more commonly affected.
  • It occurs as a paraneoplastic syndrome in association with Small Cell Carcinoma Lung in elderly patients. In young females it is usually not associated with malignancy.

Duchenne and Becker are inherited and progressive muscle dystrophies and do not show fatigability.

questions.text: Mid diastolic murmur with prominent a wave in JVP is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Among the given options, mid diastolic murmur is seen in either MS or TS.
  • A prominent a wave is seen in TS

choices.text: Oral contraceptives decrease the efficacy of anti-tubercular therapy
Rifampicin decreases the efficacy of oral contraceptives

questions.text: A female taking oral contraceptive pills developed tuberculosis. After prescribing anti-tubercular therapy, the physician advised the patient for a barrier method of contraception. What is the probable reason for this advice?
questions.solution: Rifampicin is a Cytochrome P450 enzyme inducer and drugs that are metabolized by CyP450 like warfarin, OCP, Cyclosporine etc will be reduced by co administration of Rifampicin.

questions.text: A 30 year old male weighing 70 kgs has serum sodium of 120 meq/L. What is the sodium deficit?
questions.solution:
Sodium deficit=(140-patient sodium)*body weight*0.6(0.5 for females)

(140-120)*70*0.6= 840

questions.text: A female patient feels numb on the fingertip. Her facial skin was tightened. ANA was found to be positive. Immunofluorescence showed a nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Tightening of skin, nucleolar pattern of ANA is suggestive of Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

choices.text: Admit in ICU and manage without invasive mechanical ventilation
Admit in ICU and manage with invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider hospital admission in non-ICU setting

questions.text: A 68 year male with cough, sputum and bronchial sounds. No confusion. RR 20/min, urea 44 mg/dl. BP 110/70mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The question depicts a patient with Pneumonia. The severity of pneumonia is calculated based on two scores-CURB 65 or the PSI.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables:

  • confusion (C)
  • Blood urea Nitrogen >7 mmol/L (U)(>19 mg/dL)(Blood Urea of >40 mg/dl)
  • respiratory rate ≥30/min (R)
  • blood pressure— systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg (B)
  • an age of ≥65 years.

Patients with a score of 0 (a 30-day mortality rate of 1.5%) can be treated as outpatients.

With a score of 1 or 2, the patient should be hospitalized unless the score is entirely or in part attributable to an age of ≥65 years; in such cases, hospitalization may not be necessary.

Among patients with scores of ≥3, mortality rates are 22% overall; these patients may require ICU admission

Here the CURB 65 score is 2, but the score is attributable partly to his age. Hence he can be initially managed at home with antibiotics.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient from Chattisgarh having progressive motor symptoms and leg cramps for 1 month. What history will you enquire for making a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The question deals with neurolathyrism, due to ingestion of chick pea, containing the excito toxin beta oxalylamino L alanine causing spastic paraplegia.

This disease is having high prevalence in chhattisgarh as the legume was consumed as staple food during the time of drought.

questions.text: Patient with vomiting, treated with anti-emetics. Patient was relieved of symptoms, but then later he developed abnormal movements. What is the drug to be prescribed?
questions.solution:
The question deals with drug induced extrapyramidal symptoms or movement disorders.

The culprit drugs are those which are involved in the Dopamine transmission or block the Dopamine receptors.

Usually these drugs are Neuroleptics, which are mainly used in psychiatry.

But a few drugs like Metoclopramide and prochlorperazine also have neuroleptic action and are used as antiemetics.

The classical movements include

  • dystonia the treatment is anticholinergics- benztropine or diphenhydramine or Dopamine agonists.
  • Acute movement disorders include: Dystonia. Chorea, stereotypic behaviour and tics may be seen with cocaine, amphetamines.
  • Subacute include: Akathisia
  • Chronic includes Tardive Dyskinesia.

questions.text: All of the following are the side effects of cocaine toxicity. Except?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is a psychostimulant.

The other agents belonging to this group are, Methamphetamine, MDMA and Cathinone.

There are certain therapeutically used psychostimulants too.

These include Methylphenidate and Dextroamphetamine, used in the treatment of ADHD.

Phenylpropanolamine was a psychostimulant used previously for weight reduction and is now withdrawn due to the risk of intracerebral bleed.

The table depicts the symptoms of overuse of all the psychostimulants. Their cardiovascular effects produce tachycardia and not bradycardia.

Withdrawal produces hypersomnia, depressed mood and increased appetite.

questions.text: Patient with 70% burns. A test was done on a sample collected from the burns site is shown below. An obligate aerobe bacteria was isolated from the burns victim. What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
• The dead tissue and moist environment of a burn wound creates an ideal environmentfor Pseudomonas to thrive.
  • Burn trauma can cause immunosuppression, which makes the body more susceptible to microbial colonization.

Burn site infection

  • Obligate aerobe
  • Two of the identifying biochemical characteristics of P. aeruginosa are an inability to ferment lactose on MacConkey agar and a positive reaction in the oxidase test

questions.text: A 10-year-old AIDS patient presented with fever, cough and yellowish sputum production. Examination showed bronchial breath sounds and crepitations in the right infra-scapular area. X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. CD4 count is 55. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystic jiroveci infection is specific lung infection in HIV patient but not most common.

Chest Xray findings:

Diffuse Bilateral Interstitial Infiltrates:

  • The most common finding is a widespread, symmetric, and diffuse pattern of interstitial infiltrates in both lungs.
  • These infiltrates appear as fine reticular (net-like) or granular patterns.

Ground-Glass Opacities:

  • Areas that appear hazy on the x-ray, which are indicative of partial filling of air spaces in the lungs.

questions.text: Patients with Giant cell arteritis present with history of headache, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica and mononeuritis multiplex. What should be the first line treatment?
questions.solution:
The universally accepted treatment of giant cell arteritis (GCA) is high-dose corticosteroid therapy.

The major justification for the use of corticosteroids is the impending danger of blindness in untreated patients.

questions.text: A patient is on digoxin (with some other concomitant medications). At presentation, the patient develops atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular rate and his serum digoxin raised from his previous value. Which of the following medications has enhanced digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Main mechanism of interaction- Due to strong P-glycoprotein inhibition by clarithromycin, as digoxin is a P-glycoprotein substrate.

  • In a small subset of the population, gut bacteria accounts for the percentage of digoxin metabolism. Macrolides eliminate Eubacterium lentum in the gutthrough their antimicrobial effects which may decrease digoxin metabolism, increasing its bioavailability

questions.text: A patient with on steroid therapy and having chronic urticaria now developed respiratory distress. Bronchoalveolar lavage was done and larva was seen. What is the likely parasite?
questions.solution:
Strongyloidiasis - caused by the nematode helminth, Strogyloides stercoralis

  • The infective filariform larvae penetrate the human skin and complete their parasitic life cycle by migrating through the lungs and settling in the small intestine
  • In uncomplicated strongyloidiasis, many patients are asymptomatic or have mild cutaneous and/or abdominal symptoms.
  • Recurrent urticaria, often involving the buttocks and wrists, is thecom most common cutaneous manifestation.
  • Migrating larvae can elicit a pathognomonic serpiginous eruption, larva currens ("running larva").
  • This pruritic, raised, erythematous lesion advances as rapidly as 10 cm/h along the course of larval migration
  • Patients infected with Strongyloides can be asymptomatic, or present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, urticarial skin rashes, cough, shortness of breath, and even hemoptysis in hyperinfection or disseminated disease
  • Subjects immunocompromised, or on steroids are susceptible to hyperinfection and dissemination
  • In disseminated strongyloidiasis, filariform larvae should be sought in samples obtained from sites of potential larval migration, sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, or surgical drainage fluid.

questions.text: A patient with hysteria was hyperventilating. He developed carpopedal spasm. What is the acid base abnormality?
questions.solution:
In hyperventilation, there will be CO2 wash out and respiratory alkalosis.

Chronic respiratory alkalosis is the commonest acid base anomaly in critically ill patients and indicates a poor prognosis.

questions.text: All of the following are increased in iron deficiency anemia, except?
questions.solution:
Among the iron parameters everything decreases except TRP, TIBC and RBC protoporphyrin.

Transferrin Receptor protein: Erythroid cells have the largest transferrin receptor. Hence it indicates the erythroid mass.

In absolute iron deficiency TRP increases.

Hence it can be used to differentiate between iron deficiency and anemia of chronic disease.

The above diagram shows the various stages of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient came with complaints of back stiffness, early morning stiffness for 30 min for 2 years. He now complains of bilateral heel pain. His eyes were always red looking. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
We have a young male with inflammatory back ache, enthesitis(bilateral heel pain) and ocular manifestation suggesting anterior uveitis, which points to ankylosing spondylitis.

Mechanical low back ache does not cause morning stiffness.

Disc prolapse presents with neurological symptoms. So these are ruled out.

Spinal TB is unlikely as the duration is prolonged and there are no constitutional symptoms mentioned.

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented with low back ache, early morning stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes and chest expansion (<3cm). X-ray is shown. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
According to the given History, the x-ray image shown suggests bamboo spine, which means of spinal vertebra which restricts movement of spine. This is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.

  1. Osteoporosis, x-ray typically shows decreased bone density.
  2. Mechanical disc prolapse presents with neurological symptoms and also lateral spinal x-ray shows prolapsed disc.
  3. TB spine, characteristically presence with symptoms of tuberculosis along with destruction of the vertebra.

questions.text: Patient presented with anemia, bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow study finding is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: According to given history and the HPE image showing crumpled tissue appearance suggestive of Gaucher's disease.

questions.text: A pertinent presentation with generalized fatigue and tiredness. Primary examination was uneventful. The total WBC count and different counts are normal. No immature cells were seen. Superficial discrete lymph nodes are enlarged. Biopsy of the lymph nodes shows effaced architecture, intended nucleus, prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. CD 10 and BCL2 positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: CD 10 and BCL 2 positive lymphoma is follicular lymphoma.

questions.text: An elderly female with chest X-ray showing mediastinal mass. He was diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia. What is the most probable cause of aplasia?
questions.solution:
PRCA with a mediastinal mass indicates Thymoma.

Pure red cell aplasia can be congenital or acquired.

  • Congenital PRCA is seen in Diamond blackfan syndrome. It is due to mutations in ribosomal protein genes. Responds to steroids.
  • Acquired PRCA:
  • Large granular lymphocytosis or CLL is the most common cause for PRCA.
  • Thymoma related PRCA is rare.
  • 5q deletion related PRCA is due to a defect in ribosomal protein.
  • In other causes of PRCA T cell inhibition is responsible.
  • Allogeneic stem cell transplant can also cause PRCA

questions.text: A 20 year old boy presented with fever for 1 month, gum bleeding and easy bruisability. Examination showed petechial rashes. On evaluation Hb-3g%, total count 1500, platelet count 15,000/mm3 and peripheral smear showed macrocrocytes. Bone marrow examination showed fatty streaks, absent megakaryocytes and no immature cells. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Idiopathic aplastic anemia is the most appropriate answer.

  • The peripheral smear may show macrocytes in AA.
  • Also the marrow will be readily aspirated and pale on gross examination.
  • Hematopoietic stem cells occupy <25% of marrow space.
  • Marrow will be mostly replaced by fat.
  • The cells will be normal in morphology, except being mildly megaloblastic.

The patient is having bleeding manifestations, without any other remarkable physical examination and with pancytopenia in peripheral blood. So ITP can be ruled out since other cell lines will be normal in ITP.

Myelodysplasia occurs in middle aged to elderly and the marrow will be cellular.

So we are left with PNH or idiopathic aplastic anemia.

The history given to us does not have anything in common to suspect PNH. The rule is that PNH occurs in a patient with already established aplastic anemia.

questions.text: Familial HNPCC is due to defect in?
questions.solution:
Defects in DNA repair leads to the following diseases:

Nucleotide excision repair: xeroderma pigmentosum. The exposed skin is dry and is extremely sensitive to UV rays

Mismatch repair: HNPCC. Lynch syndrome.

  • It is associated with colon cancer, more involving the proximal colon, <50 years of onset of age and predisposition to ovarian and uterine cancers.
  • AD inheritance.
  • Germline mutations lead to microsatellite instability in mismatch repair genes, involved in detection of nucleotide mismatch and slipped strand trinucleotide repeats.

Homologous recombination repair factors: Covalent DNA cross links and double stranded DNA breaks are repaired through homologous recombination.

  • Defects in these mechanisms lead toBloom's syndrome(AR. Mutation in helicase enzyme involved in homologous recombination),
  • Fanconi's syndrome(AR. More than a dozen homologous recombination genes are involved.
  • Sensitivity to chemotherapeutic agents that cause DNA cross links),Familial breast cancer genes(BRCA 1 and 2).

Defects in DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase defects are extremely rare, due to the inherent exonuclease activity which allows the enzyme to insert the proper nucleotide in the complementary strand. DNA polymerase mutation is seen in most of the endometrial and colonic carcinomas.

Regulated genomic instability in B and T cells: T and B cells, during their development undergo gene rearrangement to allow for antigenic diversification. These include the RAG 1 and 2 genes in B and T cells and the activation induced cytosine deaminase (AID). AID induced DNA breaks are prone to translocation that lead to lymphoid neoplasms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with claudication in forearm, transient loss of vision and abdominal pain. She also had weak femoral pulses. Fundus also showed retinal haemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this question, we have a young female with symptoms of upper limb claudication, visual loss, abdominal pain and weak femoral pulses.

  • The history points to the involvement of the branches of Aorta.
  • The retinal hemorrhage could be secondary to hypertension.
  • The involvement of large and medium vessels in a young female points towards the diagnosis of Takayasu Arteritis.

PAN typically involves renal and visceral vessels, ie, small and medium sized arteries. It does not produce absent peripheral pulses.

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small vessel vasculitis, mainly presenting as glomerulonephritis and pulmonary vasculitis.

Thromboangiitis obliterans(Buerger's disease) is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder of small and medium sized arteries of the distal upper and lower limb and is seen in men <40 years. Although the disease presents with claudication, larger pulses like brachial will be preserved and radial pulses will be absent.

questions.text: Male presented with feeble femoral pulses and upper limb BP- 185/90 mm Hg. Chest X-ray showed inferior rib notching. What is diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Difference in pulse and BP in upper limb and lower limb suggest towards Coarctation of aorta.

Inferior rib notching seen in COA

questions.text: Patient presented with seizure, urine osmolality 1000 mosm/kg ,serum osmolality 270 mosm/kg. On further evaluation what electrolyte abnormality is expected?
questions.solution: The scenario described here suggests SIADH.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of urine blackening on exposure to air. What is the enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
Alkaptonuria is characterized by blackening of urine on standing due to deficiency of homogentisic acid dehydrogenase.

Tyrosine metabolism disorder

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol for 3 days and presented with irritability disorientation, paranoid delusion, visual hallucinations and altered sensorium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Delirium tremens:-

  • Severe alcohol withdrawal symptoms such as shaking, confusion and hallucinations.
  • Delirium tremens usually start two to five days after the last drink and it can be fatal.
  • Some symptoms are shaking, confusion, high blood pressure, fever, seizures (worst at night), and hallucinations.

Wernicke's encephalopathy:

  • Global confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Ataxia

Korsakoff psychosis:

The triad of symptoms for Korsakoff psychosis is memory loss, learning deficits, and confabulation.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. The disease mainly affects?

A patient presented with a headache for 6 months. She took analgesics regularly. The headache has been increasing and became severe for the past 3 days, but discontinued the analgesic. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
If a person uses analgesics for a prolonged period of time, the headache becomes increasing in frequency and is resistant to preventive medications.

After stopping the analgesic, they feel improved, especially if they have been using opioids or barbiturates.

The residual headache that they experience after stopping the drug is probably the primary headache that is the underlying problem for the medication use.

The treatment of medication overuse of headache is to reduce the dose of the analgesic by 10% every 1-2 weeks.

  • Small dose NSAID can be given for residual headache and the preventive medication can be started.
  • If opioids is the culprit medication, it has to be gradually tapered and stopped and then preventive should be introduced.
  • Clonidine is used for opioid withdrawal. For day time pain, aspirin can be used.
  • For nocturnal pain, chlorpromazine is used. IV hydration and antiemetics are used.
  • The medication can be successfully withdrawn in 3-5 days, followed by institution of a short course of dihydroergotamine for 5 days, after which the preventive medications can be started.

choices.text: Increase the dose of the beta blocker

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent retrosternal chest pain, each episode lasting 3-5 min and subsiding with sublingual nitrate. Now presented in emergency with chest pain. He is a k/c/o HTN, DM, hypercholesterolemia. On losartan, aspirin, atenolol, metformin. ECG shows LVH with an inversion of the T wave. What is the next step in management
questions.solution:
In the question, the patient's pain is subsiding with sublingual nitrates, but has recurrent angina and multiple risk factors, the ideal treatment would be an early invasive treatment. But since that is not there LMWH or heparin is the next best.

The patient in the question is suffering from an acute coronary syndrome, given the T inversions, it could either be an Unstable angina or an Non St elevation MI.

The initial treatment of these consist of providing pain relief. The main anti ischemic treatments given are nitrates, Beta blockers and bed rest.

Antithrombotic treatment remains the cornerstone of treatment. Thus includes antiplatelets and anticoagulants.

Antiplatelets: in patients with NSTEMI or UA two antiplatelets should be used.

  • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor aspirin should be given in a dose of at least 162 mg followed by 75-100mg/day.
  • A P2Y12 inhibitor should be added, if there is no high risk for bleeding.
  • Clopidogrel 600 mg loading followed by 75mg/day. Other P2Y12 inhibitors are Prasugrel, 60mg loading followed by 10 mg per day. It is preferred for those in whom an invasive strategy is planned. It is contraindicated in the previous stroke, TIA. It is associated with a high bleeding risk.
  • Ticagrelor is reversible. 180 mg loading dose followed by 90 mg twice daily is used. Beneficial for both invasive as well as conservative management.
  • Cangrelor is an IV P2Y12 inhibitor which is rapid and IV. It is recommended as an adjunct in patients undergoing PCI to reduce post-procedure MI, recurrent revascularization and stent thrombosis.

Anti coagulants: unfractionated heparin, LMWH, fondaparinux and Bivaluridin are the anticoagulants used.

After giving the initial treatment, the patient has to be risk stratified to determine if the patient has to be taken up for an early PCI VS conservative management.

In high risk patients, those with multiple risk factors, ECG changes and positive troponin, an early invasive strategy should be followed which is definitely beneficial than a conservative strategy.

In low risk patients, early invasive or conservative approaches have similar outcomes. In a low risk patient, a PCI is carried out if the CT Coronary angio shows occlusion, positive stress test or raising biomarkers.

questions.text: Patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count >5000. X-ray shows a military pattern. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history and lab findings suggestive of tropical pulmonary Eosinophilia.

TROPICAL PULMONARY EOSINOPHILIA

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a distinct syndrome that develops in some individuals infected with the lymphatic- dwelling filarial species.

The majority of cases have been reported from India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Brazil, Guyana, and Southeast Asia; the decreasing incidence of TPE in last decade probably reflects global MDA efforts.

CLINICAL FEATURES

The main features include a history of residence in filaria-endemic regions, paroxysmal cough and wheezing (usually nocturnal probably related to the nocturnal periodicity of microfilariae), weight loss, low-grade fever, lymphadenopathy, and pronounced blood eosin- ophilia (>3000 eosinophils/µL).

Chest x-rays or CT scans may be normal, but generally show increased bronchovascular markings. Diffuse miliary lesions or mottled opacities may be present in the middle and lower lung fields.

Tests of pulmonary function show restrictive abnor- malities in most cases and obstructive defects in half.

Characteristically, total serum IgE levels (4-40 KIU/mL) and anti filarial antibody levels are markedly elevated.

questions.text: In a patient on maize diet with diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia which vitamin is deficient?
questions.solution:
• Pellagra is caused due to deficiency of vitamin B3 i.e niacin.
  • It is characterized by 4 Ds diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis, and death.
  • It is prevalent in people who consume maize as their staple diet

questions.text: In this patient with skin changes, what history will you ask for
questions.solution:
The picture shown is of gals necklace, a type of dermatitis, which is seen in Pellagra.

  • Pellagra is caused due to deficiency of vitamin B3 i.e niacin.
  • It is characterised by 4 Ds diarrhoea, dementia, dermatitis, and death.
  • It is prevalent in people who consume maize as their staple diet

Diet history is important in neuro Lathyrism.

questions.text: Metronidazole should not be used with?
questions.solution:
Drinking alcohol while taking metronidazole is not recommended because the combination of metronidazole and alcohol can cause a disulfiram-like reaction in some people.

Symptoms may include flushing, headaches, nausea, vomiting, and stomach cramps.
